Award.AwardTitle: IDBR: Instrument development for three-dimensional fluid flow measurements of freely-flying animals
Award.AbstractNarration:
IDBR: Instrument development for three-dimensional fluid flow measurements of freely-flying animals

Flying and gliding animals, including insects, birds, bats, and even lizards and snakes, have remarkable abilities for executing rapid maneuvers and for maintaining flight stability when perturbed by environmental factors. These capabilities form the basis of a wide variety of ecologically important flight behaviors, including escaping from predators, gathering food, and competing for mates. A comprehensive understanding of animal flight stability and control requires integrated experiments on freely flying animals responding to in-flight perturbations or generating self-motivated maneuvers, and demands quantification of the resulting three-dimensional flow around the free-flying animal.

Overcoming limitations of existing technologies, this project will develop a novel tomographic velocimetry technique for measuring three-dimensional fluid flow around freely flying animals. The aims for this new method are to provide more than five-orders-of-magnitude improvement in computational efficiency, improved flow field measurement accuracy, and an increased ease of use. Once developed, the technique and associated methodology and analysis tools will be freely distributed to the biological and engineering sciences communities.

This project will provide a transformative leap in the experimentation and instrumentation technology required to comprehensively investigate animal aerial locomotion. The new tools will enable the investigation of flight dynamics and fascinating aerial behaviors that so far have been elusive or poorly understood, and could ultimately help to answer ecological and evolutionary questions. The advancements in three-dimensional flow imaging developed here will also contribute to other areas of biology and beyond, impacting numerous research areas that touch upon fluid mechanics. The broader dissemination of the developed tools as an open-source software will provide wide accessibility to researchers and offer a platform for sustainable development.

The proposed work includes educational and outreach efforts at multiple levels. At the university level, the material developed here will serve as a basis for new courses on animal locomotion and will support the development of a university-wide research program at the interface of the biological and engineering sciences. Moreover, this project will support primary and secondary level education by working with public school teachers in under-resourced classrooms to develop novel lessons that integrate biology and engineering in a way that captures student imaginations. The results of this effort will be disseminated nationally and internationally via entertaining, freely accessible videos.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Flying and gliding animals, including insects, birds, bats, and even lizards and snakes, have remarkable abilities for executing rapid maneuvers and also for maintaining flight stability when perturbed by environmental factors.  These capabilities form the basis of a wide variety of ecologically important flight behaviors, including escaping from predators, gathering food, and engaging in aerial displays in competitions for mates.  The mechanistic bases of such behaviors are based in the combination of exquisite sensory and control systems and the unusual aerodynamics of flapping flight. 

 

Thus, a comprehensive understanding of animal flight demands quantification of the fluid mechanics of the flying animal. While isolated experiments may reveal aspects of animal flight maneuverability and stability, a complete understanding requires integrated experiments on freely flying animals responding to in-flight perturbations or generating self-motivated maneuvers. Unfortunately, such measurement capability has been elusive to this date.

 

This project aimed to develop fundamental and enabling tools for measuring the velocity fields of three-dimensional (3D) flow around free flying animals. During this effort we aimed to develop and implement state of the art volumetric reconstruction and processing methods for resolving three-dimensional flows around free flying animals and perform animal experiments to demonstrate the effectiveness and feasibility of the new methods.

 

As a result of our efforts, amongst the different significant contributions, we developed a series of new methods for modeling and quantifying the velocity measurement uncertainty for three-dimensional velocimetry.  This fundamental and broad-reaching development enables the uncertainty quantification of such measurements across the whole fluid mechanics discipline. In addition, we developed a new approach for measurement of fluid rotation, dilation, and displacement simultaneously. This methodology has opened up a new avenue of research: if combined with traditional image registration and deformation procedures, it will enable the resolution of the full deformation of a material element. This has the potential to impact a wide range of biological and mechanical system measurements in which the fluid-structure interaction yields complex deformations. This work was further augmented with the development of a new cross-correlation kernel function that dynamically accounts for the spatiotemporal variations of the signal to noise ratio in the underlying images, and creates an optimal phase-only filtering function, thus increasing the accuracy of any cross-correlation based velocimetry or image registration process.

 

This project also contributed to the development of new tools for measuring the kinematics of freely behaving animals moving in the field, another necessary component for understanding the mechanistic basis of animal flight and linking the measured fluid forces with whole animal behavior. These tools, freely available at http://argus.web.unc.edu/ have already contributed to research by teams outside the funded group.

 

Finally, in a major study we investigated how dogs drink and we discovered that the behavior is governed by the competition between gravity and fluid acceleration, and remarkably, it appears that the animal behavior has evolved to optimally account for this physical process. This discovery, beyond the biological implications, can lead to new engineering open-pumping systems.
